Room.Name: A Marble Road
Room.Description: You have left the forest and entered on a winding road paved with white marble. Gentle fields of barley and oats spread out to either side of the road, and freemen and peasants work amidst the grain. You can hear faint noises to the south where a graceful castle rises over the plains.

Exit.Description: The smooth, white marble road wends it way to the south.

Room.Name: A Marble Road
Room.Description: The road continues it way south, weaving gently around a small village at the foot of the castle, and ending abrupty at a silver gate set into the wall of the enormous white castle rising above you. Carts and horses move in and out of the castle, and as you stand here, several knights ride by, their pinnoned lances proudly held aloft.

Exit.Description: The road leads away from the castle, wending its way to the north.
The silver gates to the south lead into the castle proper.

Room.Name: Entrance Hall
Room.Description: You have entered the main hall of the castle of Camelot. The castle itself is formed of smooth white marble, and everything is polished to a high gleam. Within the hallway to the south, you can hear the sounds of festivity as the king's vassals celebrate his marriage to Lady Gwenhuevere. The king's butler stands here, looking distraught. He seizes your arm as you enter and demands that you assist him.

Exit.Description: The great silver gates of Camelot lead out onto a white marble road.
Rose Hall lies to the east, where the barracks of the castle guard are located.
The main hall leads to the south.

Room.Name: Rose Hall
Room.Description: You walk through a hall set with smooth, rose-latticed marble. The flag stones beneath your feet are a soothing pink-veined marble, and the scent of blooming flowers hangs heavy in the air. Muffled sounds of boots and laughter come from the south and east, and the room to the east is filled with drinking men.

Exit.Description: The door to the east leads into a room filled with drinking and laughing men.
Rose Hall continues to the south.
The archway to the west leads into the entrance hall of Camelot.

Room.Name: Rose Mess Hall
Room.Description: You have entered into a full-blown party. Men stand around drinking and laughing. The occasional toast to to the king is raised, and more often a toast to the new queen. Everyone seems in very good spirits, and the wine flows freely. You are hailed over and handed a glass of wine 'for luck'.

Exit.Description: The Rose Hall lies to the west. The scent of flowers drifts in from that direction.

Room.Name: Rose Hall
Room.Description: You follow the hall around the curve, and glance around. The rose arbors trail off here, though the lattices are still present. Of course, Camelot was just built two years ago, so the roses probably have not had time to cover the walls, yet. The flagstones are not as smooth here, having been pitted and worn by footsteps, and the scents in the air are of sweat and rusty metal.

Exit.Description: The roses trail a delicate line back to the hall to the north.
The hallway continues to the east, where you can hear faint sounds.

Room.Name: Rose Hall
Room.Description: The lattices continue along the walls as you enter this room, and disappear to the east. An occasional servant hurries along the hallway, carrying buckets and mops and brooms. You step aside to allow them to pass, and duck the occasional waving handle. You can hear faint sounds of snoring to the east, leading you to believe that the barracks must lie in that direction.

Exit.Description: You can hear the sounds of snoring, and very faintly, the sounds of men laughing from the east.
You can hear the sounds of a party coming from the west.

Room.Name: Rose Hall
Room.Description: You have reached the end of the Rose Hall. The lattices meant for roses trail off and end at the archway to the east. The flagstones beneath your feet are highly polished, though scarred and worn through heavy use. You can hear the sounds of soft voices coming from the door to the north, and snores and slightly louder voices from the east.

Exit.Description: The archway to the east leads into an darkened room filled with snoring men.
The lattices trail in from the west and end here.

Room.Name: Rose Barracks
Room.Description: You have entered a dark hall, filled with bunks. A few of the bunks contain snoring men. All of the bunks are made up with clean, fresh smelling linen, and there is a chest at the foot of each. The hall extends further north, where you see a fireplace, and a few men gathered around it, laughing.

Exit.Description: You can see the flicker of firelight and hear the sounds of men to the north.
The arched doorway to the west leads into the Rose Hall.

Room.Name: Rose Barracks
Room.Description: You have stumbled across of group of soldiers dicing in front of the fire. Wagering is heavy as they roll the polished bones across the floor, and groans or cheers are heard as the dice settle in place. The fireplace itself is a huge affair, hung with banners and trophies of war. A banked fire sizzles quietly in the center, and occasional sparks fly up into the air.

Exit.Description: The hall to the south is dim and silent. A faint light creeps from the archway to the southwest.

Room.Name: Officer's Quarters
Room.Description: This room is lined with cubicles that hold beds and chests. There are seven beds, and the eighth cubicle on the eastern wall holds a small stove. There are tasteful pictures decorating the walls, and a carpet thrown across the floor.

Exit.Description: The door to the south opens into the Rose Hallway.

Room.Name: Dragon Hall
Room.Description: You have entered the Dragon Hall of Camelot. The barracks within this hall are filled by the troops given to King Arthur as a wedding gift by his sister, Morgan Le Fay. You can hear the sound of a brawl to the west, and the floor is littered with debris and the remains of food.

Exit.Description: The entrance hall to Camelot lies to the east.
Dragon Hall continues to the south. You can see a mural on the far southern wall, but cannot make out any details.
You look to the west into what appears to be a barroom brawl of some sort.

Room.Name: Dragon's Mess Hall
Room.Description: The room is filled with drinking, brawling men. You narrowly avoid a mug hurled across the room, and duck aside as a man is thrown across a table at you. The room is covered with food debris, and there is garbage all over the floor. Loud singing can be heard from the corner of the room, where several men sit getting drunk.

Room.Name: Dragon Hall
Room.Description: Dragon Hall continues here. There is a large mural on the southern wall, that depicts two dragons battling over an underground lake. You recall a story once told by your village bard, about how Merlin predicted such a thing to King Vortigern, and that story eventually brought the Saxon King to his knees.

Exit.Description: Dragon Hall ends to the north, leading back into the entrance hall.
Dragon Hall continues to the west. You can smell the scent of stale beer and unwashed clothes from that direction.

Room.Name: Dragon Hall
Room.Description: You walk along Dragon Hall, amazed that in just a few, short years, such damage could have been done to such a place of beauty. Huge gouges have been hacked out of the walls, probably by an axe, and the floor is pitted and stained. The mural to the south shows the dragons rising up from the bed of the lake.

Exit.Description: Dragon Hall continues to the west, with the head of the mural.
The hallway to the west looks, if anything, more damaged than the one you are currently standing in.

Room.Name: Dragon Hall
Room.Description: You have reached the end of the Dragon Hall. Tables lie overturned here and the floor is pitted and scarred. Obscene words (misspelled) are carved in the walls, and scrawled across the wall hangings. The stench of unwashed bodies and clothing hangs thickly in the air here, and you gag slightly at the stink.

Exit.Description: The doorway to the north leads into the officer's quarters of the Dragon Guard
You gaze back towards the east at the beginning of Dragon Hall.
You look with trepidition to the west, where you can see a series of bunks with snoring men on them.

Room.Name: Officer's Quarters
Room.Description: The officer's quarters you have entered remind you more of some of the finer pig stys you have visited. The smell in the air is reminiscent of old laundry and mold. The beds are unmade, and the linen looks as if it hadn't been changed in several weeks. There is dirty clothing strewn about the room, and you spot several dirty dishes in one corner.

Exit.Description: The doorway to the south leads into the (comparatively) neat Dragon Hall.

Room.Name: Dragon Barracks
Room.Description: You have truly entered the lion's den (or dragon's den, as the case may be) of iniquity. All around you, bunks are filled with snoring men, who perhaps last saw a bath at the beginning of this decade. To the north you can see a small group of men, laughing about a small form that is trapped in the midst of their circle.

Exit.Description: You can see a group of men and and a small, struggling form to the north.
Dragon Hall lies to the east, into relatively cleaner air than what you've encountered in this hall.

Room.Name: Dragon Barracks
Room.Description: You have stumbled upon a scene that you swore could never again happen under the reign of King Arthur. As you walk into the room, you interrupt the assault and near violation of a young serving girl being tormented by several of the guardsmen. They look up as you enter and roar in anger at the intrusion.

Exit.Description: The room to the south is filled with snoring, unwashed men.

Room.Name: Main Hall
Room.Description: The main hall of Camelot is truly one of the wonders of the world. The floor is carpeted (truly amazing, since most castles make do with rushes for the floors) and the walls are hung with priceless egyptian hangings. Tables rest against the wall, bearing upon them priceless pieces of art, some of which look as if a breath might shatter them.

Exit.Description: The entrance to the castle of Camelot lies to the north.
The main hall continues to the south, where you can hear the faint sounds of a party.

Room.Name: Main Hall
Room.Description: You continue south along the main hall of the castle. Servants hurry by you occasionally, barely glancing up as they hurry along on their various errands. This section of the hall is filled with weapons displays. Swords of ancient kings hang from the walls, and other types of weapons hang in racks or rest in display cases.

Exit.Description: The hall to the north is filled with priceless antiques and artifacts.
The main hall of Camelot stretches out before you to the south.

Room.Name: Main Hall
Room.Description: The main hall of Camelot gracefully enters into an intersection here. The smooth white marble of the floor is polished to a high sheen, and the walls have been scrubbed til they shine. To the south somewhere you can hear the sounds of celebration. Chapel Hall lies to the west, and Servant's Hall lies to the east.

Exit.Description: You can see a weapons display to the north.
The doorway to the east leads into the Servant's Hall.
The main hall of Camelot continues south from here.
The archway to the west leads to chapel hall. All of the castle inhabitants are faithful children of the church.

Room.Name: Chapel Hall
Room.Description: You have left the busy main hall, and turned off into the Chapel Hall of Camelot. The occasional acolyte hurries past you, and a group of ladies walks through, back towards the main hall. The air is quiet here, and you can smell the faintest hint of incense. The priest's rooms are to the north, and Chapel Hall continues to the west.

Exit.Description: The doorway to the north leads into the private chambers of Camelot's priest.
The archway to the east leads back into the main hall of Camelot. The archway is decorated with fleur-di-lies and roses.
Chapel Hall continues to the west.

Room.Name: Sitting Room
Room.Description: Everything about this room has obviously been picked for the amount of guilt it will inspire in the leadership of Camelot. From the wall hangings of Mary in childbirth (as the queen was raised in a christian nunnery) to the statues of Oedipus (to remind the king of his guilt with his sister), everything here has obviously been carefully planned and arranged.

Exit.Description: The doorway to the south leads into a less guilt-inspiring room that this.
The doorway west leads into the bedroom of Father Benedict.

Room.Name: Father Benedict's Bedroom
Room.Description: Everything about this room defies the normal perception of priests as "celibate" or "austere". The huge, king sized bed sitting in the middle of the room is obviously intended for (and has obviously been used for) more than just sleeping. Richly carved chests and drawers are strewn about the room, some of them lying open to reveal the treasures within. This one is full of rich clothing, obviously for use by the good priest when he's not on call or duty, while that one is filled wrist deep with large, sparkling gemstones.

Exit.Description: The doorway to the west leads to the sitting room.

Room.Name: Chapel Hall
Room.Description: Chapel Hall continues here, leading east and west into further sections. This area is dedicated to the display of every kind of cross available on the market today. Huge ones, tiny ones, ones made out of gold, even a cross made out of seaweed.

Exit.Description: The beginning of Chapel Hall lies to the east.
Chapel hall ends to the west.

ExtraDescription.Description: Okay, for those of you who are confused: + + ===+=== + + + +

Room.Name: Chapel Hall
Room.Description: You have reached the end of Chapel Hall. All around you, the hall is silent, except for the quiet murmur of voices from the west. The occassional acolyte hurries by, intent upon his own errands. The floor is polished to a smooth sheen, and the walls are covered by wall hangings depicting the fall from paradise.

Exit.Description: Chapel hall continues the east.
To the west you can see the entrance to the chapel. The archway is adorned with flowers and spring branches.

Room.Name: Chapel Entrance
Room.Description: The entrance to the chapel is lined with votive candles and donation boxes. Several of the candles have been lit, and the donation boxes sag with the offerings that have been placed here. Servants hurry back and forth, cleaning up the chapel area after the wedding. The scent of incense is heavy in the air, and you breath shallowly, hoping to be away from here before you pass out from the fumes.

Exit.Description: To the north you can see the altar and pews of the chapel.
The archway to the east leads into Chapel Hall.

Room.Name: Chapel
Room.Description: The chapel of Camelot is a truly wondrous room. The walls are carved in bas-relief with scenes from the bible.... Moses descending from the mountain with the ten commandments, Noah leading the animals into the ark, and so on. The pews are carved out of cherrywood, and shined to a high polish. The altar is covered with a heavily embroidered altar cloth, jeweled with rubies and sewn with gold.

Exit.Description: The door to the east leads into the chapel's confessional. You can hear faint sounds from that direction.
The chapel entry lies to the south in a blaze of candles.

Room.Name: Confessional
Room.Description: You have intruded upon a confession taking place in this confessional. A young man that you identify as Sir Galahad kneels here, sobbing out his sins to the priest. You catch something about the queen in his ramblings, and wonder what the queen has to do with him. The priest is listening to the confession with a rather calculating expression on his face, and you have a feeling that whatever Galahad is telling him, the priest will use it to his advantage in the future.

Exit.Description: The door to the west opens into the chapel proper.

Room.Name: Servant's Hall
Room.Description: You have entered the Servant's Hall of Camelot. Looking around you can see that even the servants here live in luxury. Small carpets are thrown across the floor, which shines like a jewel in the lamplight. No rude torches line the walls here, the hall instead being lit by oil lamps set in holders lining the walls. To the north you can see the servants quarters, and the hall continues to the east.

Exit.Description: This doorway leads into the servant's quarters.
The Servant's Hallway continues on to the east.
This archway leads out into the main hall of Camelot.

Room.Name: Servant's Quarters
Room.Description: You have entered the servant's quarters of Camelot. Bunk beds line the walls of this room, and chests and wardrobes rest beside them. The room is empty of all life, save for a cat and her kittens resting by the hearth. The room is neatly made up, and all of the bunks are freshly made with clean linen. The room smells of polish and soap, and you are reminded of your mother's bedroom at home.

Exit.Description: The doorway to the south leads into the Servant's Hall.

Room.Name: Servant's Hallway
Room.Description: This section of the hallway is relatively quiet, with only occasional servants passing you, bearing platters and flagons toward the dining hall, where the marriage celebration is in full swing. The floors are smooth and clean, and the walls are hung with pictures and hangings.

Exit.Description: The doorway to the north enters into a messy, private room.
Servant's Hallway continues on to the east.
Servant's Hallway continues its path to the west.

Room.Name: Cook's Quarters
Room.Description: This well-appointed room is obviously the home of the castle's cook. Every around you, half carved cooking implements, and cookbooks are scattered acroos the room. There is no one here but a large white dog that raises its head as you enter and happily wags its tail.

Exit.Description: The doorway to the south leads into the the Servant's Hallway.

Room.Name: Servant's Hallway
Room.Description: You have reached the end of Servant's Hallway. The hall here is extremely busy as servant's hurry from the kitchen to the storerooms to the main hall with dishes and flagons and towels. The floor here is slightly greasy from the kitchen activities, and footing is slightly treacherous.

Exit.Description: The kitchen of Camelot rests to the north.
The door to the east opens into what appears to be a storage room.
Servant's Hallway continues on a slightly cleaner path to the west.

Room.Name: Storage Room
Room.Description: This storage room is filled with a large variety of foodstuffs and basic castle supplies. Against the back walls the wine racks rest, and other types of alcohol. Dishes and pots and pans all are stored here, as well, and an impressive variety of utensils. Servants hurry in and out of this room, gathering supplies necessary for the festivities.

Exit.Description: The doorway enters into the Servant's Hallway.

Room.Name: Kitchen
Room.Description: The kitchen is a madhouse of activity, due to the wedding festivities that are taking place. Servants are running madly about, organizing platters, filling flagons with mead, wine, beer and water, and carrying food out and empty plates in. There are cats weaving in and out of the tables and legs, snatching bites of food whereever they can find them.

Exit.Description: The insanity of the kitchen continues to the east.
The archway to the south leads a slightly greasy trail into Servant's Hallway.

Room.Name: Kitchen
Room.Description: The kitchen here is dedicated to several large tables, filled with food and serving utensils. Servants line the table, chopping and preparing dishes, and two large fireplaces host huge joints of roasting meat. The floor is slippery here with grease and other food particles and footing is hazardous.

Exit.Description: The kitchen extends on to the west.

Room.Name: Main Hall
Room.Description: The main hall comes to an end here, with the Throne room to the south. Armor lines the walls of this corridor, some of it dating back to the first Roman conquerers of Britain. The floor is polished smooth, but you can see the marks of many boots that have passed over it in the last few hours. To the south you can see a great party going on.

Exit.Description: The hallway extends far to the north, pausing only at intersections.
The hallway ends here, leaving the Throne Room to the south.

Room.Name: Throne Room
Room.Description: You enter into the throne room off Camelot and stare around you in awe. Everywhere, lamplight shines of the mellowness of gold trimming and jeweled fittings. The white marble floor has been buffed to an incredibly high shine, and the walls are hidden behind the rich hangings from all around the world. King Arthur, and his new Queen, Guenhuevere, sit on their golden thrones, watching over the festivities of the wedding feast.

Exit.Description: The main hall of Camelot begins to the north.
There is a doorway to the east that leads into the Queen's Hall.

ExtraDescription.Description: The castle is only part of the world. So much lies in the great outdoors. The makers of this banner believe that some clues to life can be found outside. You see a small picture featuring two boats and two trees. A rock lies nearby, and it is quite unusual, better look at it.

Room.Name: Queen's Hall
Room.Description: You emerge from the sound and light into the relative calm of Queen's Hall, so named for the Queen's Council Chamber that lies off of it. The flagstones beneath your feet are of a mellow golden color, and the walls are hung with clothes embroidered with scenes of spring.

Exit.Description: Queen's Hall continues to the east.
The doorway to the west leads into the Throne Room, where the wedding festivities are taking place.

Room.Name: Queen's Hall
Room.Description: You glance around as you continue down Queen's Hall. You notice that the flagstones are darkening as you walk to a golden brown, very close to the shade of the Queen's hair. The wall's are hung here with tapestries covered with the pictures of a perfect summertime, and there is not a speck of dust to be seen.

Exit.Description: You look to the north, where you can see what appears to be a private dining chamber.
Queen's Hall continues to the east.
Queen's Hall begins to the west.

Room.Name: Private Dining Room
Room.Description: This room contains a small table, laid with servings for two. Obviously it is intended to give the King and Queen a private dinner before they retire to their bedchambers. The settings on the table are of silver and gold, and the glasses are carved out of solid pieces of ruby.

Exit.Description: The doorway to the south opens back into the Queen's Hall.
The archway to the west leads into a private council chamber.

Room.Name: Private Council Chamber
Room.Description: This council chamber contains a small table and three chairs. It is obviously intended for very private meetings (unless the accounts of the Round Table have been grieviously exaggerated). The walls are panelled with a dark, soothing wood, and the floor beneath your feet is carpeted.

Exit.Description: There is a private dining chamber lying to the east.

Room.Name: Queen's Council Chamber
Room.Description: You have entered the Queen's Council Chamber. There is no table in this room, rather a large selections of comfortable chairs, each with a pile of knitting or embroidery beside it. The impression that you get from this room is that very little serious discussion goes on here, but rather a lot of gossip and girl talk.

Exit.Description: Queen's Hallway lies to the east, and past that, the Throne Room.

Room.Name: Queen's Hall
Room.Description: Queen's Hall comes to an end here, with archways leading off north and east. The stones here are a dark brown with faint streaks of gold running through them. The walls are hung with hangings depicting the woodlands in autumn, the riot of red, brown and orange almost bringing you the scent of falling leaves.

Exit.Description: The archway to the north leads into a small dining hall, filled with drinking men.
The Queen's Council Chamber lies to the east.
Queen's Hall continues to the west.

Room.Name: Dining Hall
Room.Description: You enter a room filled with men laughing and talking cheerfully amidst themselves. Flagons off mead are passed freely as the knights of the Round Table celebrate their king's marriage. You look around and see many famous (and imfamous) faces... Mordred, the king's nephew (or is he?) , Perces, Pellinore, Tristan, and many others. To the east lies a drinking room, where the men can retire once the dinner is done.

Exit.Description: You look into the room to the east and see several comfortable couches and a few end tables.
Queen's Hall, the jewel of Camelot, lies to the south.

Room.Name: Drinking Lounge
Room.Description: This drinking lounge is filled with comfortable chairs (most of which are in very poor condition, possibly due to men sitting on them while wearing sharp implements). The walls are lined with shelves, full of all sorts of alcohol and liquor. The floor is hardwood, with a few rugs thrown over it to relieve the boredom. The floor, carpets and furniture are all covered with burn marks.

Exit.Description: The archway to the west leads into a dining hall filled with drinking men.

Room.Name: King's Hall
Room.Description: You have entered King's Hall, truly the crown of the castle. Golden flagstones beneath your feet give off a mellow shine, and the walls appear to be carved from a single gemstone, though where such a stone could be found, you have not idea. To the north is the room containing the Round Table, and King's Hall continues to the west.

Exit.Description: The doorway to the north leads into the hall that contains the Round Table.
The archway to the east opens back into the throne room.
King's Hall continues to the west.

Room.Name: Round Table
Room.Description: You stop with awe as you look upon the Round Table, truly the epitome of King Arthur's castle. As its name states, it is round, with chairs seated along it's edge. The king's chair is obvious by its golden trimmings, and the Siege Perilous also, by the roped off area around it. The floor has been brightly polished, and the walls are scrubbed to a shine.

Exit.Description: The hall to the south leads into the King's Hall.

Room.Name: King's Hall
Room.Description: You continue down King's Hall, pausing now and again to examine a wall hanging or a suit of armor. Everything here speaks of good taste and elegance. The golden floor is adorned with the occasional rug from the far east, and the walls and floor have been scrubbed to a bright shine.

Exit.Description: The archway to the north leads into the king's bedchamber, where you can see the king's squire preparing the room.
King's Hall begins to the east.
King's Hall continues to the west.

Room.Name: King's Bedchamber
Room.Description: You have entered the king's bedchamber. The first thing that draws your eyes is the huge bedstand, easily big enough for several people to sleep in. You glance around and also notice a plethora of chests and wardrobes, all neatly closed and shined. A huge bearskin rug is thrown across the foot of the bed. The king's squire is here, straightening the room.

Exit.Description: The doorway to the south leads back into the King's Hallway.

Room.Name: King's Hall
Room.Description: You stroll along King's Hall, admiring the mellow shine of gold beneath your feet and the ruby shine from the walls. From the east you can hear faint sounds of laughter. You step back in startlement as a loud explosion from the archway to the north rocks the hallway. The laughter from the east doesn't pause at the sudden noise, so you assume that it must be a normal occurance, and look north to try and determine the cause.

Exit.Description: You peer to the north into a maze of tubing and strange experiments.
You can hear the sounds of a party going on to the east.
King's Hallway ends to the west.

Room.Name: Merlin's Laboratory
Room.Description: You have walked into a madhouse of color and sound. Tubes and vials and wires and piping run throughout the room, making footing and head room rather hazardous. A lumpy bed lies along one wall, piled high with papers and gadgets. A short man with greying hair peers into a tangle of wires sitting on a table in front of him.

Exit.Description: The archway to the south leads to the relatively peaceful King's Hallway.

Room.Name: King's Hallway
Room.Description: You have reached the end of King's Hallway. There is a huge golden chandelier hanging from the ceiling here, casting weird shadows from the wall hangings. You can hear the faint sounds of laughter to the east, where the wedding feast is taking place, and you can see the Queen's Bedchamber to the north.

Exit.Description: You look to the north into the Queen's Bedchamber. You can see a woman moving around the room.
King's Hallway continues to the east.

Room.Name: Queen's Bedchamber
Room.Description: You have entered the Queen's bedchamber, an austere room that reminds you of a nun's cubicle. Your eyes are drawn to the far wall, where a cross hangs above the bed, the articulated carving of the Christ staring down at you in accusation. The floor is bare of coverings, and the walls are covered with religious paintings rather than wall hangings. A young woman bustles about the room, straightening it up.

Exit.Description: The doorway to the south leads into the King's Hallway.

Room.Name: Rose Clan Vestibule
Room.Description: Love fills your heart in this room. A portrait of the rose clan leaders of past and present is on the wall. Many a virgin have offered themslves as a sacrifice for the good of the clan here. Rose recall is north. A sign says: Please leave extra clan orbs and lanterns on the floor after you kill the virgin, and don't forget your portal. You see the Greyhaven alter to the north and a hallway to the south. Type 'look list' for a list of what lantern goes with which clevel.

ExtraDescription.Description: All the leaders have a halo aura because of the good deeds they have performed.

The following lanterns are to be used for the clevels. Clevel 1 (Vassal) is to get a red rose lantern. Clevel 2 (Knight) is to get a pink lantern. Clevel 3 (Templar) is to get a blue lantern. Clevel 4 is to get a yellow lantern, and the gold ones are for clevel 5. Naturally, white rose orbs are for anyone in the clan. Thanks for looking after these, Ulf

NPC.name: page
NPC.description: A young child stands before you dressed in the reds and golds of Camelot.
NPC.longDescription: A page of Camelot

NPC.name: Rose Guard
NPC.description: A guard standing proudly in the red and gold of King Arthur strolls in front of you.
NPC.longDescription: A guard of the Royal Rose patrols here.

NPC.name: squire rose
NPC.description: This young man proudly wears the device of a squire of the Royal Rose Guard.
NPC.longDescription: A Squire of the Royal Rose Guard stands here.
NPC.shortDescription: a squire of the Rose Guard

NPC.name: guard gambling
NPC.description: A guard in a rumpled uniform kneels on the flagstones before the fireplace, rolling a set of dice in his hands and praying for luck.
NPC.longDescription: A guard kneels on the floor here, dicing with his companions.

NPC.name: officer guard rose
NPC.description: This officer rests on his bunk here, quietly drinking a toast to the health of the king and queen.
NPC.longDescription: An officer of the Rose Guard rests here on his bunk.
NPC.shortDescription: an officer of the Rose Guard

NPC.name: guard off duty
NPC.description: An off duty guardsman raises his glass in a toast to the new queen.
NPC.longDescription: An off duty guardsman is drinking here.

NPC.name: drunken guard
NPC.description: A drunk guard lounges on a chair here, nursing a drink and leering at the serving wenches
NPC.longDescription: A drunken Dragon Guard lounges here.

NPC.name: Dragon guard
NPC.description: A Dragon Guard looks at you suspiciously as you pass by him.
NPC.longDescription: A Dragon Guard is patrolling the hall here.

NPC.name: guard violent
NPC.description: A drunk and disorderly Dragon Guard looks up from what he was doing and roars in anger at your intrusion.
NPC.longDescription: A violent Dragon Guard roars in anger at your intrusion.

NPC.name: officer dragon
NPC.description: You have wandered in on a sleeping officer of the Dragon Guard. You wonder if you can sneak back out before he wakes up.
NPC.longDescription: An officer of the Dragon Guard sleeps here.
NPC.shortDescription: an officer of the Dragon Guard

NPC.name: servant kitchen
NPC.description: A kitchen servant hurries along here. He glances up as he passes you and smiles merrily at you.
NPC.longDescription: A kitchen servant hurries along on an errand.

NPC.name: Cabal dog
NPC.description: Cabal, the king's favorite hound, lies sleeping by the hearth.
NPC.longDescription: A white dog lies by the hearth, sleeping peacefully

NPC.name: cat
NPC.description: You stumble across a grey and white cat, who opens its eyes and glares at you with the arrogance only a cat can truly achieve.
NPC.longDescription: A cat lies sleeping on the hearth here.

NPC.name: Cook
NPC.description: A cook, dressed impeccably in white linen, is chopping onions here. Tears fill your eyes as the fumes hit you and you wonder how he can stand it.
NPC.longDescription: One of Camelot's cooks is chopping vegetables here.

NPC.name: monk
NPC.description: A monk, dressed in the brown robes of his order, glares up at you in accusation as you walk past him.
NPC.longDescription: A monk glares up at you from the folds of his robe.

NPC.name: brother
NPC.description: A franciscan brother raises a cross in the air and spouts some nonsense about God destroying this world to create a new one.
NPC.longDescription: A brother of the cloth intones "God destroys the wicked"

NPC.name: Galahad
NPC.description: Sir Galahad is a handsome young man with golden hair and a sweet smile. He is looking particularly hag-ridden right now, probably due to some imagined sin he has committed.
NPC.longDescription: Sir Galahad pours out his sins to the priest.

NPC.name: priest father john
NPC.longDescription: Father John, the castle priest, sits listening to Galahad with a bored expression.

NPC.name: altar boy
NPC.description: An altar boy, dressed in the white and crimson of the priesthood, lounges here, waiting for Father John to return and give him some- thing to do.
NPC.longDescription: An altar boy lounges here, waiting for the priest's return.

NPC.name: footman
NPC.description: A young man, dressed in the red and gold of Camelot, hurries along on an errand here.
NPC.longDescription: A footman hurries along on an errand.

NPC.name: King Arthur
NPC.description: King Arthur sits on his throne, watching over the wedding festivities. He is a young man with brown hair and eyes, and a ready smile.
NPC.longDescription: King Arthur sits on his throne, watching over the wedding festivities.

NPC.name: queen guenhuevere
NPC.description: Queen Guenhuevere glares at you suspiciously, ready to be insulted by anything you say to her. She has long golden hair and blue eyes.
NPC.longDescription: Queen Guenhuevere sits here, ready to take insult at anything you say to her.

NPC.name: knights errant
NPC.description: A knight dressed in shining plate mail stands before you. He raises a hand as you pass by and says "Ho, traveller. Have you heard any tales of injustice that I might take action against?"
NPC.longDescription: A knight intent upon errantry stands here.

NPC.name: knight black
NPC.description: A knight dressed in shining plate mail stands before you. He raises a hand as you pass by and says "Ho, traveller. Have you heard of any tales of injustice I might join in?"
NPC.longDescription: A black knight glares at you as you pass by him.

NPC.name: wench serving
NPC.description: A serving wench is cleaning the room here. She picks up a glass, give it a quick polish, then smiles at you.
NPC.longDescription: A serving wench is cleaning the room here.

NPC.name: butler
NPC.description: One of the king's butlers stands in the center of the room, ordering its arrangement.
NPC.longDescription: A king's butler supervises the arrangment of the room.

NPC.name: lady queen
NPC.description: One of the queen's ladies sits here, gossiping with her friends.
NPC.longDescription: The queen's lady sits in her chair here, happily embroidering and gossiping.

NPC.name: Tristan
NPC.description: Sir Tristan stands before you, a tall man with flowing golden hair and mustache. He has a look about him, though, as if he is seeking something more.
NPC.longDescription: Sir Tristan drinks a toast to the queen's health.

NPC.name: Lancelot
NPC.description: Sir Lancelot, a short man with black hair, sits in a corner moping.
NPC.longDescription: Sir Lancelot sits sighing in a corner.

NPC.name: Kay
NPC.description: Sir Kay sits on a chair, propping his lame leg up. He is a sullen looking man with dark hair and eyes.
NPC.longDescription: Sir Kay lounges on a chair here, drinking heavily.

NPC.name: Mordred
NPC.description: Sir Mordred, a small dark man with icey black eyes, glares at you from the chair he rests in.
NPC.longDescription: Sir Mordred looks at you sardonically.

NPC.name: butler
NPC.description: One of the king's butlers stands in the center of the room, ordering its arrangement.
NPC.longDescription: A king's butler supervises the arrangment of the room.

NPC.name: squire king
NPC.description: A king's squire stands here, eager and ready to serve the king at his whim.
NPC.longDescription: One of the king's squires stands here ready to serve him.

NPC.name: merlin
NPC.description: Merlin stands here, trying to get an experiment of his to work.
NPC.longDescription: Merlin, the king's wizard, is working here.

NPC.name: Morgause
NPC.description: Morgause sits at Merlin's feet, intent on learning everything she can from him.
NPC.longDescription: Morgause, the King's sister, sits learning from Merlin.

NPC.name: lady queen
NPC.description: One of the queen's ladies is here, gossiping with her friends.
NPC.longDescription: The queen's lady sits in her chair her, happily embroidering and gossiping.

NPC.name: butler bedevere
NPC.description: Sir Bedevere grabs your arm as you enter the castle and begins telling you a story of woe and distress. King Arthur (after having slept with his sister, Morgause, and conceived a bastard son by her, Mordred), has married Guenhuevere, who is in love with Lancelot. Guenhuevere and Lancelot are not sleeping with each other yet, but it can only be a matter of time, and meanwhile Mordred (who is a snake) is sneaking around behind the king's back, stirring up trouble, and Morgause is with Merlin, trying to learn all the sorcerer's secrets.
NPC.longDescription: Sir Bedevere, the king's butler and cupbearer, stands here looking distraught.

NPC.name: rose virgin
NPC.description: She looks so good!
NPC.longDescription: A rose virgin is here.

NPC.name: darth
NPC.longDescription: (no long description)

NPC.name: maroon tunes
NPC.longDescription: A maroon tune bounces here

NPC.name: piss ass asshole shit fuck damn crap cunt pussy dick penis dickhead tit tits titty fag crap smartass
NPC.longDescription: A gainer stands here.

Item.Name: dagger page
Item.LongDescription: A page's dagger rests on the floor here.

Item.Name: rose earrings
Item.LongDescription: A pair of rose earrings rests on the table here.

Item.Name: mace rose
Item.LongDescription: A mace of the royal Rose Guard lies on the ground.

Item.Name: dragon earrings
Item.LongDescription: A pair of dragon earrings rests on the table here.

Item.Name: boots riding
Item.LongDescription: A pair of riding boots lie crumpled in the corner

Item.Name: dice
Item.LongDescription: You roll this pair of dice in your hands reflectively.

Item.Name: shield honor
Item.LongDescription: A shield of honor catches your attention in the corner.

Item.Name: dragon whip
Item.LongDescription: A dragon whip is hanging on the wall here.

Item.Name: shield gain
Item.LongDescription: A shield of gain hangs on the wall here.

Item.Name: knee britches
Item.LongDescription: A pair of knee britches done in a tasteful black lie here.

Item.Name: cat collar
Item.LongDescription: A cat's collar has fallen off of a cat.

Item.Name: white gloves
Item.LongDescription: A pair of dog-eaten white gloves lie here.

Item.Name: apron servant's
Item.LongDescription: A servant's apron lies crumpled on the floor

Item.Name: hatchet
Item.LongDescription: A hatchet used for chopping up onions is here.

Item.Name: white kerchief
Item.LongDescription: A white kerchief has been tossed onto the floor.

Item.Name: monk robe
Item.LongDescription: A brown, sackcloth robe lies here.

Item.Name: stole brother
Item.LongDescription: A stole of the brotherhood of Christ lies here.

Item.Name: cross
Item.LongDescription: A holy cross lies abandoned here.

Item.Name: ruby ring
Item.LongDescription: A ruby ring, part of the spoils of tithe, rests here.

Item.Name: caliburn sword
Item.LongDescription: Caliburn, King Arthur's famous sword, lies here.
Item.ExtraFlags: Glow Hum Frost Sharp TwoHands Poison Unholy

Item.Name: crown golden
Item.LongDescription: Queen Guenhuevere's golden crown

Item.Name: white belt
Item.LongDescription: A knight's white belt is rolled up here.

Item.Name: cleaning rag
Item.LongDescription: A cleaning rag perfect for wrapping about the wrist sits here.

Item.Name: flowered lance
Item.LongDescription: A lance here has been covered with flowers to celebrate the wedding.

Item.Name: Isobel ring
Item.LongDescription: Isobel's ring, her gift to Tristan, is laying on a table here.

Item.Name: Guenhuevere's favor
Item.LongDescription: Queen Guenhuevere's favor, her gift to Lancelot, is resting here.

Item.Name: glasses kay
Item.LongDescription: Kay's glasses rest on the table here.

Item.Name: flail innocents
Item.LongDescription: Mordred's flail of the innocents rests here.

Item.Name: ladies scarf
Item.LongDescription: A ladies' scarf lies abandoned on the floor.

Item.Name: towel linen
Item.LongDescription: A linen towel, faintly damp, lies here.

Item.Name: bracelet ruby
Item.LongDescription: A ruby bracelet scrolled with the royal Pendragon rests here.

Item.Name: owl merlin's
Item.LongDescription: An owl sits on Merlin's shoulder, peering around intently.

Item.Name: Siege Perilous
Item.LongDescription: The Siege Perilous, perhaps the most (in)famous chair of Camelot, rests here.

Item.Name: plague pill
Item.LongDescription: A plague pill

Item.Name: blue rose lantern
Item.LongDescription: A blue lantern is here.

Item.Name: pink rose lantern
Item.LongDescription: A pink lantern is here.

Item.Name: golden rose lantern
Item.LongDescription: A golden lantern is here.

Item.Name: yellow rose lantern
Item.LongDescription: A yellow lantern is here.

Item.LongDescription: A rose virgin portal is here.

Item.LongDescription: A Friendship Charm

Item.Name: cloak many colors
Item.LongDescription: A cloak of many colors{s

Item.LongDescription: Quest potion

Item.ShortDescription: the Nether Stormseeker of Sylvan Spririts
Item.LongDescription: You see a spear with Darkmoon's insignia here.

Item.LongDescription: A dagger with a blade like a sliver of darkness rests here.

Item.LongDescription: A cookie is here. Better eat it before cookie monster does.
